77B8E0E62C7445FF98F74B6751FD0BA5.description: Motivation can lead to commitment, personal development, and increased levels of engagement.

98EC72BCA4B349D2964429208C12F82E.description: Motivation can lead to exposure to a variety of physical activities.

3FF1197F6A0C44869EEC5551CD1A72AA.description: Motivation can lead to development of movement skills.

B49463F99FAC412C909CD4077CB5FB50.description: Moderate-to-vigorous physical activities include rhythmic, gymnastic, expressive, individual, challenging, adventurous and cultural.

D7967D7BA99A4403B387E4DE7363E818.description: Physical activity guidelines recommend between 30 to 60 minutes of moderate-to-vigorous daily physical activity.

97C7AE1EAD274B70A010BB8AEE549AFB.description: Type is the physical activity selected.

C6182184B8904CF7AC1386D55B9ED6DA.description: Time is how long an individual is engaged in physical activity.

FDF6C24850924EC38D9FE03CFBFFFA06.description: Intensity is the level of physical exertion experienced during physical activity.

A17F378799254237A706C18B3BBE5639.description: Frequency is how often an individual is engaged in physical activity.

68B7D694C44A4E42852741C8042C0567.description: Motivation is supported by setting goals and monitoring progress toward those goals. Training principles include frequency, intensity, time and type.

26E4D2D5364F4B32B5739039B0D63A49.description: Students analyze motivation and its relationship to personal development and active living.

EF0AE3CEAA38439996A6CA10BBA97E04.description: Active Living: Developing physical literacy through movement and active living supports well-being across a lifespan.
